Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices
Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:
High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.
Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

High Level Float Switch

Each main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.
Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The high pressure receivers of P1 and the controlled pressure receiver of P2 are both equipped with a single main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout their respective systems.
Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)

The entrances to each machinery room are equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside their respective machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.

1.2.6 Process Classification

Each ammonia refrigeration system at SunWest Fruit Company consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at SunWest Fruit Company are treated as two (2) ind

ized below:
Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A §15.3.8;
All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank; 
Diffusion Tank

The refrigeration systems are equipped with a single ammonia diffusion tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping for both systems is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tank. The ammonia diffusion tank is 11.9' dia. x 36' high (30,000 gallon capacity). At a water level of 18', the tank contains 15,000 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A §15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.

Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:
High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.
Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.
High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, SunWest Fruit Company has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, 
scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 SunWest Fruit Company, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that SunWest Fruit Company has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name           | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)
South System             Anhydrous Ammonia           31,000
West System              Anhydrous Ammonia           16,000


Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Pr

epared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

1.2.1 Facility Overview

SunWest Fruit Company operates a commercial cold storage for citrus products in Parlier, CA. The facility has two ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

P1 South System
(1) Bin Room
(2) Hydrocoolers
(3) Rooms
(2) Precoolers
(1) Hallway
(4) Degreening Rooms

P2 North System
(5) Rooms
(1) Loading Dock
(10) Conditioning Rooms

1.2.2 Facility Location

SunWest Fruit Company is located at 755 Manning Ave, Parlier, CA 93648. The latitude and longitude of the controlled pressure receiver is 36.607225, -119.529138. The facility is located approximately 7.5 miles east of state highway 99 in an industrial area surrounded primarily by businesses.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "a special flood hazard area". The elevation of the machinery room was designed with the flood hazards in mind.

SunWest Fruit Company is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that SunWest Fruit Company has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.

1.2.4 Process Chemistry

The refrigeration system employed at SunWest Fruit Company is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:

High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Controlled Pressure Receiver

The purpose of the controlled pressure receiver (CPR) is to provide a safe location to add and store liquid ammonia at a constant pressure in the refrigeration system. The CPR receives liquid from the thermosyphon vessel that is supplied by the condenser. The CPR is maintained at an intermediate pressure that is less than the condensing pressure, but greater than the suction pressure. From the CPR, liquid is supplied to each zone of refrigeration. The CPR is also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The CPR is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop

the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the CPR contains intermediate pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Flooded Accumulators

The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulators. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Direct Expansion)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the high pressure receivers or the controlled pressure receiver. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the

pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the main suction accumulators.

Hydrocoolers

The purpose of the hydrocoolers is to remove heat from water which is used to precool fresh fruit. The hydrocoolers receive liquid from flooded accumulators. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the hydrocoolers and is returned to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the hydrocoolers contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Main Suction Accumulators

The purpose of the main suction accumulators is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulators receive vapor from the flooded accumulators and separate any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulators drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessels. The main suction accumulators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulators contain low pressure vapor ammonia.

Liquid Transfer Vessels

The purpose of the liquid transfer vessels is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration systems back to the high pressure receivers or controlled pressure receiver. The liquid transfer vessels receive liquid from the main suction accumulators. Once the liquid lev

el in the liquid transfer vessel reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into the high pressure receivers/controlled pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessels can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.

Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulators and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.

Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators and hydrocoolers to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers or thermosyphon vessel. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver/thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Thermosyphon Vessel

The purpose of the thermosyphon vessel is to provide a supply of liquid ammonia necessary to cool the oil in the compressors. The thermosyphon vessel receives high pressure liquid from the condenser and supplies high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon oil coolers on the connected screw co

mpressors. Excess liquid in the thermosyphon vessel is piped to the controlled pressure receiver. High pressure ammonia vapor formed in each oil cooler is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the thermosyphon vessel contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.
Oil Coolers

The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through them. The oil coolers receive liquid from the thermosyphon vessel. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil coolers and is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the oil coolers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

1.2.5 Safety Systems

Ammonia Detection System

Each room containing ammonia refrigeration equipment is equipped with an ammonia detector. Either a Calibration Technologies GG-NH3 or a Honeywell EC-F9-NH3 provide low concentration detection and alert personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm via the accompanying audible/visual alarms. An additional warning is triggered at 50 ppm and the equipment is shut off at 80 ppm. With each trigger the PLC notifies facility personnel and the local fire department. 

Emergency Control Box

The Emergency Control Boxes (ECB) are installed on the north exterior wall of P1 machinery room and the north exterior wall of the P2 machinery room; each box contains three (3) valves.
Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve
Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve
Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. 
Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summar

ependent processes.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.
SunWest Fruit Company has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the SunWest Fruit Company facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

SunWest Fruit Company has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

SunWest Fruit Company's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR §3220
Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the f

acility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 
Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

SunWest Fruit Company has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, SunWest Fruit Company continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved SunWest Fruit Company's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that SunWest Fruit Company's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.
SunWest Fruit Company has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, SunWest Fruit Company has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, SunWest Fruit Company now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for SunWest Fruit Company employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program SunWest Fruit Company will continue
to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
